canonical_explanation.text: A relation R on set A is reflexive if (a,a)∈R for all a∈A, symmetric if (a,b)∈R implies (b,a)∈R, and transitive if (a,b)∈R and (b,c)∈R implies (a,c)∈R. A relation that is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive is called an equivalence relation. A function f:A→B is one-one (injective) if f(a₁)=f(a₂) implies a₁=a₂, onto (surjective) if every element in B has a pre-image, and bijective if it is both. The composition (fog)(x) = f(g(x)). A function is invertible if and only if it is bijective.
rules: A relation R on set A with n elements: total relations = 2^(n²)
Equivalence relation partitions the set into disjoint equivalence classes
For bijective f: A→B, f⁻¹ exists and f⁻¹of = Iₐ, fof⁻¹ = I_B
Composition of functions is associative: fo(goh) = (fog)oh
A binary operation * on A is commutative if a*b = b*a for all a,b ∈ A

questions.question_text: A relation R on set A is called reflexive if:

options.text: (a, a) ∈ R for every a ∈ A
(a, b) ∈ R and (b, c) ∈ R implies (a, c) ∈ R

questions.explanation_correct: A relation R on set A is reflexive if (a, a) ∈ R for every element a in A. Every element must be related to itself.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A defines symmetric, option C defines transitive, and option D defines the universal relation. Reflexive means every element is related to itself: (a, a) ∈ R for all a ∈ A.

questions.question_text: Let A = {1, 2, 3} and R = {(1,1), (2,2), (3,3), (1,2), (2,1)}. Which properties does R satisfy?
questions.explanation_correct: R is reflexive: (1,1), (2,2), (3,3) are all present. R is symmetric: (1,2) and (2,1) are both present. R is transitive: (1,2) and (2,1) gives (1,1) which is present; (2,1) and (1,2) gives (2,2) which is present. So R is an equivalence relation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Check all three properties: reflexive (all diagonal pairs present), symmetric (if (a,b) then (b,a) present), and transitive (if (a,b) and (b,c) then (a,c) present). All three hold here.

questions.question_text: The relation R on the set of integers Z defined by R = {(a, b) : a − b is divisible by 3} is:
questions.explanation_correct: Reflexive: a − a = 0 is divisible by 3. Symmetric: if 3|(a−b), then 3|(b−a) since b−a = −(a−b). Transitive: if 3|(a−b) and 3|(b−c), then 3|(a−b+b−c) = 3|(a−c). Hence R is an equivalence relation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Verify all three properties. Since a−a=0 is divisible by 3 (reflexive), if a−b is divisible by 3 then so is b−a (symmetric), and if a−b and b−c are divisible by 3 then a−c = (a−b)+(b−c) is also divisible by 3 (transitive).

questions.question_text: The relation R = {(1,1), (2,2)} on the set A = {1, 2, 3} is reflexive.
questions.explanation_correct: The relation is not reflexive because (3, 3) is not in R. For reflexivity, (a, a) must be in R for every element a in A, including 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reflexive requires (a, a) ∈ R for ALL a ∈ A. Here A = {1, 2, 3} but (3, 3) ∉ R, so R is not reflexive.

questions.question_text: A relation which is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A relation that satisfies all three properties — reflexive, symmetric, and transitive — is called an equivalence relation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A partial order is reflexive, antisymmetric, and transitive. Universal and empty relations are specific types. The combination of reflexive + symmetric + transitive defines an equivalence relation.

questions.question_text: Let R be the relation on A = {1, 2, 3, 4} defined by R = {(1,2), (2,1), (1,1), (2,2), (3,3), (4,4), (3,4), (4,3)}. The equivalence classes are:
questions.explanation_correct: R is an equivalence relation. Elements 1 and 2 are related to each other (and to themselves), forming equivalence class {1, 2}. Elements 3 and 4 are related to each other (and to themselves), forming equivalence class {3, 4}.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An equivalence relation partitions the set into equivalence classes. Since 1~2 and 3~4 (but 1 is not related to 3 or 4), the partition is {1, 2} and {3, 4}.

questions.question_text: The number of equivalence relations on the set {1, 2, 3} containing (1, 2) is:
questions.explanation_correct: If (1,2) ∈ R, then by symmetry (2,1) ∈ R, and by reflexivity (1,1), (2,2), (3,3) ∈ R. Now either 3 is in its own class giving partition {{1,2},{3}}, or 3 is in the same class as 1 and 2 giving partition {{1,2,3}}. So there are exactly 2 equivalence relations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since (1,2) must be in R, elements 1 and 2 must be in the same equivalence class. The only question is whether 3 is in a separate class or the same class. This gives exactly 2 possibilities.

questions.question_text: The relation R on Z defined by R = {(a, b) : a ≥ b} is:

options.text: Reflexive and transitive but not symmetric
Reflexive and symmetric but not transitive
Symmetric and transitive but not reflexive

questions.explanation_correct: Reflexive: a ≥ a is true for all a. Transitive: if a ≥ b and b ≥ c, then a ≥ c. Not symmetric: 3 ≥ 2 but 2 is not ≥ 3. So R is reflexive and transitive but not symmetric.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Check each property. a ≥ a always holds (reflexive). a ≥ b does NOT imply b ≥ a (not symmetric, e.g., 5 ≥ 3 but 3 < 5). If a ≥ b and b ≥ c then a ≥ c (transitive).

questions.question_text: Let R be the relation on the set N × N defined by (a, b) R (c, d) if and only if ad = bc. Which equivalence class does (1, 2) belong to?
questions.explanation_correct: (a,b) R (1,2) means a·2 = b·1, i.e., 2a = b. So the equivalence class of (1,2) = {(a, 2a) : a ∈ N} = {(1,2), (2,4), (3,6), ...}. These are all pairs representing the fraction 1/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The relation ad = bc captures the idea of equal fractions: a/b = c/d. The equivalence class of (1,2) consists of all (a,b) with a/b = 1/2, i.e., b = 2a: {(1,2), (2,4), (3,6), ...}.

questions.question_text: Let R be a relation on the set A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} defined by R = {(a, b) : |a − b| is even}. How many equivalence classes does R have?
questions.explanation_correct: |a − b| is even when a and b have the same parity. The equivalence classes are: odd numbers {1, 3, 5} and even numbers {2, 4}. So there are 2 equivalence classes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: |a − b| is even exactly when a and b are both even or both odd. This partitions A into {1, 3, 5} (odd) and {2, 4} (even), giving 2 equivalence classes.

questions.question_text: Let A = {1, 2, 3, ..., 9} and R be the relation on A defined by (a, b) ∈ R if and only if a ≡ b (mod 3). The equivalence class [7] is:
questions.explanation_correct: 7 mod 3 = 1. The equivalence class [7] consists of all elements in A that give remainder 1 when divided by 3. These are: 1, 4, 7. So [7] = {1, 4, 7}.
questions.explanation_incorrect: a ≡ 7 (mod 3) means a ≡ 1 (mod 3) since 7 = 3×2 + 1. From A = {1,...,9}, elements with remainder 1 on division by 3 are: 1, 4, 7.

questions.question_text: The total number of relations that can be defined on a set with 2 elements is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A relation on a set with n elements is a subset of A × A, which has n² elements. Total relations = 2^(n²) = 2^(2²) = 2^4 = 16.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A × A has n² = 4 elements when n = 2. Each element either belongs or does not belong to the relation, giving 2^4 = 16 possible relations.

questions.question_text: A function f: A → B is called one-one (injective) if:

options.text: Every element of B has a pre-image in A
f(a₁) = f(a₂) implies a₁ = a₂ for all a₁, a₂ ∈ A
f is both one-one and onto
f(a) = a for all a ∈ A

questions.explanation_correct: A function is one-one (injective) if distinct elements of A map to distinct elements of B, i.e., f(a₁) = f(a₂) implies a₁ = a₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A defines onto (surjective), option C defines bijective, and option D defines the identity function. One-one means no two distinct elements map to the same image.

questions.question_text: The function f: R → R defined by f(x) = x² is:
questions.explanation_correct: Not one-one: f(2) = f(−2) = 4 but 2 ≠ −2. Not onto: negative numbers like −1 have no pre-image since x² ≥ 0 for all x ∈ R. So f is neither one-one nor onto.
questions.explanation_incorrect: f(x) = x² fails one-one because f(2) = f(−2) = 4. It fails onto because no real x satisfies x² = −1. Hence it is neither one-one nor onto.

questions.question_text: The function f: R → R defined by f(x) = 3x + 5 is:
questions.explanation_correct: One-one: if 3x₁ + 5 = 3x₂ + 5, then x₁ = x₂. Onto: for any y ∈ R, x = (y − 5)/3 ∈ R gives f(x) = y. Hence f is bijective.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A linear function f(x) = ax + b with a ≠ 0 from R to R is always bijective. It is one-one (different inputs give different outputs) and onto (every real number is achieved).

questions.question_text: The function f: N → N defined by f(n) = 2n is onto.
questions.explanation_correct: f is not onto because odd natural numbers (like 1, 3, 5, ...) have no pre-image. For example, there is no n ∈ N such that 2n = 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For f to be onto N, every natural number must be in the range. But f(n) = 2n only produces even numbers (2, 4, 6, ...), so odd numbers have no pre-image.

questions.question_text: If f: {1, 2, 3} → {a, b, c} is a bijection, how many such bijections are possible?
questions.explanation_correct: A bijection from a set of 3 elements to a set of 3 elements is a permutation. The number of bijections = 3! = 3 × 2 × 1 = 6.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The number of bijections from a set of n elements to a set of n elements equals n! (n factorial). Here n = 3, so the answer is 3! = 6.

questions.question_text: Let A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {4, 5}. The number of onto functions from A to B is:
questions.explanation_correct: Total functions from A to B = 2³ = 8. Non-onto functions map all 3 elements to a single element in B: there are 2 such functions. Onto functions = 8 − 2 = 6.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using inclusion-exclusion: total functions = 2³ = 8. Functions missing 4 from range = 1 (all map to 5). Functions missing 5 from range = 1 (all map to 4). Functions missing both = 0. So onto = 8 − 1 − 1 + 0 = 6.

questions.question_text: The function f: R → R defined by f(x) = x³ is:
questions.explanation_correct: One-one: if x₁³ = x₂³, then x₁ = x₂ (cube root is unique for reals). Onto: for any y ∈ R, x = y^(1/3) ∈ R satisfies f(x) = y. Hence f is bijective.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unlike x², the function x³ is strictly increasing over all of R, making it one-one. Every real number has a real cube root, so it is onto. Therefore f(x) = x³ is bijective.

questions.question_text: Let f: N → N be defined by f(n) = n + 1 for odd n and f(n) = n − 1 for even n. Then f is:
questions.explanation_correct: f swaps consecutive pairs: f(1)=2, f(2)=1, f(3)=4, f(4)=3, f(5)=6, f(6)=5, ... Each pair {2k−1, 2k} is swapped. This is a bijection since every natural number appears exactly once as an image, and distinct inputs give distinct outputs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The function pairs odd and even consecutive numbers and swaps them. Since every natural number is either odd or even, and each swap is a bijection within each pair, f is bijective on N.

questions.question_text: Let f: R − {3} → R − {1} be defined by f(x) = (x − 2)/(x − 3). Then f is:
questions.explanation_correct: One-one: if (x₁−2)/(x₁−3) = (x₂−2)/(x₂−3), cross-multiplying gives (x₁−2)(x₂−3) = (x₂−2)(x₁−3). Expanding: x₁x₂ − 3x₁ − 2x₂ + 6 = x₁x₂ − 3x₂ − 2x₁ + 6, which simplifies to −x₁ = −x₂, so x₁ = x₂. Onto: for any y ≠ 1, solving y = (x−2)/(x−3) gives x = (3y−2)/(y−1) which is in the domain. Hence f is bijective.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cross-multiply to prove one-one. For onto, solve for x in terms of y: x = (3y − 2)/(y − 1), which is defined for y ≠ 1 and gives x ≠ 3. So the codomain R − {1} is fully covered.

questions.question_text: If f: A → B is a bijection and A has 5 elements, then B must have ___ elements.
questions.explanation_correct: A bijection is both one-one and onto. One-one requires |A| ≤ |B|, and onto requires |A| ≥ |B|. Together, |A| = |B| = 5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a bijection to exist between finite sets A and B, they must have the same number of elements. Since |A| = 5, we need |B| = 5.

questions.explanation_correct: Every element maps to a unique element (one-one): f(1)=2, f(2)=3, f(3)=4, f(4)=1. The range = {1, 2, 3, 4} = codomain (onto). So f is bijective.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Check: all images are distinct (one-one), and the range {2,3,4,1} = {1,2,3,4} = codomain (onto). Hence f is bijective — it is a cyclic permutation.

questions.question_text: If f(x) = 2x + 3 and g(x) = x², then (fog)(x) is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: fog means apply g first, then f. So (fog)(x) = f(g(x)). First g(x) = x², then f(x²) = 2x² + 3. Option B would be (gof)(x).

questions.question_text: If f(x) = 2x + 3 and g(x) = x², then (gof)(x) is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: gof means apply f first, then g. So (gof)(x) = g(f(x)) = g(2x+3) = (2x+3)². Expanding: 4x² + 12x + 9.

questions.question_text: If f: R → R is defined by f(x) = 3x − 4, then f⁻¹(x) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let y = 3x − 4. Solving for x: x = (y + 4)/3. So f⁻¹(x) = (x + 4)/3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To find f⁻¹, set y = f(x) = 3x − 4, then solve for x in terms of y: 3x = y + 4, so x = (y + 4)/3. Replace y with x to get f⁻¹(x) = (x + 4)/3.

questions.question_text: A function f is invertible if and only if f is:
questions.explanation_correct: A function is invertible if and only if it is bijective (both one-one and onto). One-one ensures the inverse is well-defined (single-valued), and onto ensures the inverse is defined on the entire codomain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Being one-one alone is not sufficient (the inverse would not cover the entire codomain). Being onto alone is not sufficient (the inverse might not be single-valued). Both conditions are needed, i.e., bijective.

questions.question_text: If f(x) = x + 1 and g(x) = 2x − 1, then (fog)(3) is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: First compute g(3) = 2(3) − 1 = 5. Then f(5) = 5 + 1 = 6. So (fog)(3) = 6.

questions.question_text: If f(x) = 2x + 1 and g(x) = 3x − 2, then (fog)(2) − (gof)(2) equals:
If f: R → R is defined by f(x) = 5x + 2, then f⁻¹(17) is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: First find f⁻¹(x): from y = 5x + 2, we get x = (y−2)/5. So f⁻¹(x) = (x−2)/5. Then f⁻¹(17) = 15/5 = 3.

questions.question_text: Let f: R → R be defined by f(x) = (4x + 3)/(6x − 4), x ≠ 2/3. Then (fof)(x) equals:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Substitute f(x) into f again. After simplification, the numerator becomes 34x and denominator becomes 34, giving (fof)(x) = x. This means f = f⁻¹, i.e., f is self-inverse (an involution).

questions.question_text: Let f(x) = x³ and g(x) = x^(1/3). Then (gof)(x) is:
questions.explanation_correct: (gof)(x) = g(f(x)) = g(x³) = (x³)^(1/3) = x. Since g is the inverse of f, their composition gives the identity function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: g(f(x)) = (x³)^(1/3) = x^(3·1/3) = x¹ = x. This is the identity function, confirming g = f⁻¹.

questions.question_text: Composition of functions is commutative, i.e., fog = gof always.
questions.explanation_correct: Composition is NOT commutative in general. For example, if f(x) = 2x and g(x) = x + 1, then (fog)(x) = 2(x+1) = 2x+2, but (gof)(x) = 2x+1. Since 2x+2 ≠ 2x+1, fog ≠ gof.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A counterexample disproves commutativity: let f(x) = 2x and g(x) = x+1. Then fog(x) = 2x+2 but gof(x) = 2x+1. However, composition IS associative: fo(goh) = (fog)oh.

questions.question_text: If f: {1,2,3} → {a,b,c} is given by f(1) = a, f(2) = b, f(3) = c, then f⁻¹(b) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Since f(2) = b and f is a bijection, f⁻¹(b) = 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: f⁻¹(b) asks: which element maps to b under f? Since f(2) = b, the answer is 2.

questions.question_text: Let f(x) = 2x − 1 and g(x) = (x + 1)/2. Then f⁻¹ is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: To find f⁻¹, solve y = 2x−1 for x: x = (y+1)/2. So f⁻¹(x) = (x+1)/2, which is exactly g(x). One can verify fog = gof = identity.

questions.question_text: A binary operation * on a set A is a function from:
questions.explanation_correct: A binary operation * on A takes two elements of A and produces an element of A. Formally, it is a function *: A × A → A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A binary operation takes an ordered pair of elements from A and assigns a single element in A. So it maps from A × A to A.

questions.question_text: The binary operation * defined on Z by a * b = a + b − 1 is:
questions.explanation_correct: Commutative: a*b = a+b−1 = b+a−1 = b*a. Associative: (a*b)*c = (a+b−1)*c = a+b−1+c−1 = a+b+c−2. Also a*(b*c) = a*(b+c−1) = a+b+c−1−1 = a+b+c−2. Since both equal a+b+c−2, it is associative.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Check commutativity: a+b−1 = b+a−1 (yes, addition is commutative). Check associativity: (a*b)*c = a+b+c−2 = a*(b*c). Both properties hold.

questions.question_text: The identity element for the binary operation * defined on Q by a * b = a + b − ab is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let e be the identity element. Then a * e = a for all a, i.e., a + e − ae = a, which gives e(1 − a) = 0. For this to hold for all a, we need e = 0. Verify: a * 0 = a + 0 − 0 = a and 0 * a = 0 + a − 0 = a. So e = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For identity e: a + e − ae = a implies e − ae = 0, so e(1−a) = 0. Since this must hold for all a (including a ≠ 1), we need e = 0.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a binary operation on N (natural numbers)?
questions.explanation_correct: Subtraction is not a binary operation on N because a − b may not be a natural number when a < b. For example, 2 − 5 = −3 ∉ N. A binary operation must always produce a result in the same set.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A binary operation on N must map N × N into N (closure). Addition, multiplication, and GCD of natural numbers always give natural numbers, but subtraction can give negative results (e.g., 1 − 3 = −2 ∉ N).

questions.question_text: The binary operation * defined on R by a * b = a + b is associative.
questions.explanation_correct: Since a * b = a + b, we have (a*b)*c = (a+b)+c = a+(b+c) = a*(b*c) by associativity of addition. So * is associative.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The operation is just addition, and addition of real numbers is associative: (a+b)+c = a+(b+c). Hence the binary operation is associative.

questions.question_text: The binary operation * on Z defined by a * b = a + b + 1 has identity element:
questions.explanation_correct: Let e be the identity. Then a * e = a, i.e., a + e + 1 = a, giving e = −1. Verify: a * (−1) = a + (−1) + 1 = a, and (−1) * a = −1 + a + 1 = a. So e = −1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Solve a + e + 1 = a for e: e + 1 = 0, so e = −1. Check both sides: a*(−1) = a−1+1 = a and (−1)*a = −1+a+1 = a. Identity is −1.

questions.question_text: For the binary operation * on Z defined by a * b = a + b + 1, the inverse of element 3 is:
questions.explanation_correct: The identity element is e = −1 (from a + e + 1 = a). For the inverse of 3, we need 3 * b = −1, i.e., 3 + b + 1 = −1, giving b = −5. Verify: 3 * (−5) = 3 + (−5) + 1 = −1 = e.
questions.explanation_incorrect: First find identity: e = −1. Then solve 3 * b = e: 3 + b + 1 = −1, so b = −5. Check: (−5) * 3 = −5 + 3 + 1 = −1 = e. So the inverse of 3 is −5.

questions.question_text: The binary operation * on R − {−1} defined by a * b = a + b + ab is:
questions.explanation_correct: Commutative: a + b + ab = b + a + ba (yes). Identity: a*e = a+e+ae = a, so e(1+a) = 0, giving e = 0. Associative: (a*b)*c = (a+b+ab)*c = a+b+ab+c+ac+bc+abc. Also a*(b*c) = a*(b+c+bc) = a+b+c+bc+ab+ac+abc = a+b+c+ab+ac+bc+abc. Both are equal. So all three properties hold.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Note that a*b = a+b+ab = (1+a)(1+b)−1. This makes checking properties easier. The identity is 0 and the inverse of a is −a/(1+a).

questions.question_text: The binary operation * on {0, 1, 2, 3, 4} defined by a * b = (a + b) mod 5 has the inverse of 3 as:
questions.explanation_correct: The identity element is 0 (since a + 0 mod 5 = a). For the inverse of 3, we need 3 * b = 0, i.e., (3 + b) mod 5 = 0. So b = 2 since (3 + 2) mod 5 = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Under addition mod 5, the identity is 0. The inverse of 3 is the element b such that 3 + b ≡ 0 (mod 5), which gives b = 2.

questions.question_text: The binary operation * defined on Q − {0} by a * b = ab/2 has identity element:
questions.explanation_correct: a * e = a implies ae/2 = a, so e/2 = 1, giving e = 2. Verify: a * 2 = a·2/2 = a and 2 * a = 2a/2 = a. So the identity is 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Solve ae/2 = a for e: e = 2. Check: a*2 = 2a/2 = a and 2*a = 2a/2 = a. The identity element is 2.

questions.question_text: For the binary operation * on Q − {0} defined by a * b = ab/2, the inverse of element 5 is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The identity is 2 (since ae/2 = a gives e = 2). For the inverse of 5: 5 * b = 2, i.e., 5b/2 = 2, giving b = 4/5. Verify: 5 * (4/5) = 5·(4/5)/2 = 4/2 = 2 = e.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Identity is 2. Solve 5b/2 = 2: 5b = 4, b = 4/5. Check: (4/5)*5 = (4/5)(5)/2 = 4/2 = 2. The inverse of 5 is 4/5.

questions.question_text: If f(x) = (x − 1)/(x + 1) for x ≠ −1, then (fof)(x) = ___.
Let R be the relation on Z defined by (a, b) ∈ R if a² ≡ b² (mod 4). The number of equivalence classes is:
questions.explanation_correct: a² mod 4 is either 0 (when a is even, since (2k)² = 4k²) or 1 (when a is odd, since (2k+1)² = 4k²+4k+1). So a² ≡ b² (mod 4) iff a and b have the same parity. This gives 2 equivalence classes: even integers and odd integers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Even numbers: a² ≡ 0 (mod 4). Odd numbers: a² ≡ 1 (mod 4). So a² ≡ b² (mod 4) iff both are even or both are odd. Two equivalence classes.

questions.question_text: The binary operation * on R defined by a * b = (a + b)/2 is:
questions.explanation_correct: Commutative: (a+b)/2 = (b+a)/2 (yes). Associative: (a*b)*c = ((a+b)/2 + c)/2 = (a+b+2c)/4. But a*(b*c) = (a + (b+c)/2)/2 = (2a+b+c)/4. Since (a+b+2c)/4 ≠ (2a+b+c)/4 in general (try a=0, b=0, c=4: 8/4=2 vs 4/4=1), * is not associative.
questions.explanation_incorrect: (a+b)/2 = (b+a)/2, so commutative. But (a*b)*c = (a+b+2c)/4 while a*(b*c) = (2a+b+c)/4. These are unequal when a ≠ c, so not associative.

questions.question_text: The total number of one-one functions from {1, 2, 3} to {a, b, c, d} is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a one-one function from a 3-element set to a 4-element set: first element has 4 choices, second has 3, third has 2. Total = 4 × 3 × 2 = 24. This is P(4,3) = 4!/(4−3)! = 24.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The number of one-one functions from an m-element set to an n-element set (m ≤ n) is P(n,m) = n!/(n−m)!. Here P(4,3) = 4!/1! = 24.
